smell_analysis.justification: All diagrams in the provided PDF contain visible elements and are not empty.
All use cases in the 'Lendude funktsionaalne allsüsteem' diagram (Page 2) are connected to an actor, either directly or via 'include' relationships to use cases that are connected to actors.
No actors were found associated with multiple use cases having synonymous names.
No distinct elements with identical names were found within the same package scope.
No redundant data copies without Foreign Keys were detected in the database models. Data duplication (like 'lennukituup_kood' in 'Lend') is supported by Foreign Key constraints.
Use case naming is consistent on Page 2, using the imperative verb form (e.g., 'Vaata', 'Registreeri', 'Tühista').
All states in the 'Lennu seisundidiagramm' (Page 12) are reachable via transitions from the start node.
All actions in the activity diagrams (Pages 3 and 4) are reachable from the start nodes.
All visible relationships in the class and database diagrams define multiplicity (e.g., 0..*, 1) at both ends.
The Use Case diagram on Page 2 contains 19 central elements (use cases). The State diagram on Page 12 contains 13 central elements (states). Both exceed the threshold of 10.
On Page 11 (Class Diagram), the class 'Lend' has 7 visual connection lines to other elements. On Page 19 (Database Diagram), the table 'Lend' has 6 visual connection lines.
The layout of the diagrams is generally compact and consistent; no significant outliers in element distance were observed.
All use cases and activity actions start with a verb (e.g., 'Vaata', 'Algatab', 'Määrab').
No class, table, attribute, or use case names were found with 3 or fewer characters.
The class/table name 'kuupäevade_vahemiku_maandumiskeeld' (Page 14 and Page 23) starts with a lowercase letter.
The attribute 'Kood' in class 'Lennujaam' (Page 14) starts with an uppercase letter.
The database table 'Lennujaama_vastuvoetavad_lennukituubid' (Page 23) uses a plural name ('lennukituubid').
No type prefixes (like tbl_, str_) were found in element names. Prefixes like 'lj_' in 'lj_nimetus' appear to be abbreviations of the table name, not data type indicators.
